# Weekly Content Skill

## Skill Purpose
Provides standards and guidelines for creating and maintaining weekly learning entries, ensuring consistent structure, quality content, and proper formatting across all weekly README files.

## Core Responsibilities

### 1. Weekly Entry Creation
Guide the creation of new weekly README files following the established template

### 2. Structure Validation
Ensure all weekly entries maintain consistent section structure

### 3. Content Quality
Help craft meaningful, well-formatted learning documentation

### 4. Navigation Management
Maintain proper previous/next week navigation links

## Weekly Entry Structure

### Required Components

Every weekly README must include:

1. **Title and Date Range** (H1)
2. **Week at a Glance** (Blockquote summary)
3. **Six Topic Sections** (H2) - even if empty
4. **Week Summary** (H2)
5. **Navigation Links** (Footer)

### Complete Template Structure

```markdown
# Week XX, YYYY (Month DD - Month DD)

> **Week at a Glance**: [1-2 sentence summary]

---

## üíª AI, Data & Programming

### What I Learned
- 

### Projects & Practice
- 

### Resources
- 

### Reflections
> 

---

## üí∞ Finance & Money

### What I Learned
- 

### Actions Taken
- 

### Resources
- 

### Reflections
> 

---

## ‚úàÔ∏è Travel & Culture

### What I Learned
- 

### Experiences
-

- 

### Reflections

-

[‚Üê Previous Week](../week-XX/README.md) | [Main README](../../../README.md) | [Next Week ‚Üí](../week-XX/README.md)
```

## Topic Section Guidelines

### üíª AI, Data & Programming

**Focus**: Technical learning, coding, data science, AI/ML, tools

**Subsections:**
- **What I Learned**: New concepts, languages, frameworks, tools
- **Projects & Practice**: Code written, projects built, exercises completed
- **Resources**: Documentation, tutorials, courses, books
- **Reflections**: Thoughts on technical growth, challenges overcome

**Content Examples:**
```markdown
### What I Learned
- Learned React hooks (useState, useEffect, useContext) for state management
- Understood the difference between SQL joins (INNER, LEFT, RIGHT, FULL)
- Discovered how to use GitHub Actions for CI/CD automation

### Projects & Practice
- Built a weather dashboard using React and OpenWeather API
- Completed 10 algorithm challenges on LeetCode (arrays and strings)
- Set up automated testing pipeline with Jest and GitHub Actions

### Resources
- [React Hooks Documentation](https://react.dev/reference/react) - Official guide
- [LeetCode](https://leetcode.com) - Algorithm practice platform
- Book: "Clean Code" by Robert Martin - Chapters 1-3

### Reflections
> React hooks finally clicked this week after building three small projects. The key was understanding hooks as a way to "hook into" React features, not just random functions. State management feels much more intuitive now.
```

### üí∞ Finance & Money

**Focus**: Personal finance, investing, budgeting, economics, business

**Subsections:**
- **What I Learned**: Financial concepts, investment strategies, economic principles
- **Actions Taken**: Budget adjustments, investments made, financial tracking
- **Resources**: Books, podcasts, articles, courses
- **Reflections**: Insights on money management, wealth building mindset

**Content Examples:**
```markdown
### What I Learned
- Understood the concept of dollar-cost averaging in index fund investing
- Learned about the 50/30/20 budgeting rule (needs/wants/savings)
- Discovered tax advantages of Roth IRA vs Traditional IRA

### Actions Taken
- Set up automatic monthly contributions to index funds ($500/month)
- Tracked all expenses for the week using YNAB app
- Increased emergency fund to 3 months of expenses

### Resources
- [The Simple Path to Wealth](https://jlcollinsnh.com) by JL Collins - Chapters 1-5
- Podcast: "Choose FI" episode on index fund investing
- [Mr. Money Mustache Blog](https://mrmoneymustache.com) - Early retirement strategies

### Reflections
> The compound interest calculator really put things in perspective. Starting to invest consistently in my 20s could mean hundreds of thousands more by retirement. Time is the most powerful financial tool I have right now.
```

### ‚úàÔ∏è Travel & Culture

**Focus**: Travel experiences, cultural learning, languages, geography

**Subsections:**
- **What I Learned**: Cultural insights, language learning, geography knowledge
- **Experiences**: Trips taken, places explored, cultural events attended
- **Resources**: Travel blogs, language apps, cultural guides
- **Reflections**: Perspectives on travel, cultural understanding

**Content Examples:**
```markdown
### What I Learned
- Learned 50 new Spanish vocabulary words focused on food and dining
- Discovered the history of Japanese tea ceremony and its cultural significance
- Understood visa requirements for travel to Southeast Asia

### Experiences
- Attended a local Vietnamese cultural festival, tried authentic pho
- Explored a new neighborhood in the city I hadn't visited before
- Had a language exchange conversation with a native Spanish speaker

### Resources
- Duolingo app - Daily 15-minute Spanish lessons
- [Atlas Obscura](https://atlasobscura.com) - Unusual travel destinations
- YouTube: "Easy Spanish" channel for conversational practice

### Reflections
> Practicing Spanish with a native speaker was intimidating but incredibly valuable. I realized I know more than I thought, but need more confidence in speaking. Cultural immersion, even in small doses, makes language learning more meaningful.
```

### üå± Personal Development

**Focus**: Self-improvement, productivity, habits, mindset, career growth

**Subsections:**
- **What I Learned**: New skills, productivity techniques, mindset shifts
- **Skills Practiced**: Habits worked on, techniques applied, goals pursued
- **Resources**: Books, courses, podcasts, mentors
- **Reflections**: Personal insights, growth observations

**Content Examples:**
```markdown
### What I Learned
- Learned the Pomodoro Technique for focused work sessions (25 min work, 5 min break)
- Discovered the concept of "atomic habits" - small changes compound over time
- Understood the difference between fixed and growth mindset

### Skills Practiced
- Used Pomodoro timer for deep work sessions (completed 8 pomodoros today)
- Woke up at 6 AM for 5 out of 7 days this week
- Practiced active listening in conversations by asking follow-up questions

### Resources
- Book: "Atomic Habits" by James Clear - Chapters 4-7
- App: Forest - Focus timer with gamification
- Podcast: "The Tim Ferriss Show" - Episode on morning routines

### Reflections
> The Pomodoro Technique works surprisingly well for me. Breaking work into 25-minute chunks makes big tasks less overwhelming. I'm actually getting more done in less time by building in breaks rather than trying to power through.
```

### üí™ Health & Fitness

**Focus**: Physical health, exercise, nutrition, sleep, wellness

**Subsections:**
- **What I Learned**: Health information, nutrition facts, fitness principles
- **Activities & Habits**: Workouts completed, meals prepared, health practices
- **Resources**: Fitness apps, nutrition guides, health articles
- **Reflections**: Observations on physical and mental wellness

**Content Examples:**
```markdown
### What I Learned
- Learned proper form for deadlifts to prevent back injury
- Understood the role of protein timing for muscle recovery
- Discovered the connection between sleep quality and exercise performance

### Activities & Habits
- Completed 4 strength training sessions (push/pull/legs split)
- Ran 15 miles total this week (3 runs: 5 miles each)
- Prepared 5 high-protein meals for the week (meal prep Sunday)
- Averaged 7.5 hours of sleep per night

### Resources
- [StrongLifts 5x5](https://stronglifts.com) - Strength training program
- MyFitnessPal app - Nutrition tracking
- YouTube: Jeff Nippard's channel - Science-based fitness

### Reflections
> Consistency is more important than intensity. I feel better after a week of moderate, consistent exercise than I do after sporadic intense workouts. Building the habit of showing up is the real win, even on days when I don't feel motivated.
```

### ‚ù§Ô∏è Relationships, Life & Family

**Focus**: Relationships, family time, social connections, life balance

**Subsections:**
- **What I Learned**: Relationship insights, communication skills, life lessons
- **Quality Time & Connections**: Time spent with loved ones, meaningful interactions
- **Resources**: Books on relationships, articles on communication
- **Reflections**: Personal insights on relationships and life

**Content Examples:**
```markdown
### What I Learned
- Learned about the "5 love languages" and identified mine as quality time
- Understood the importance of setting boundaries in relationships
- Discovered techniques for active listening and empathetic responses

### Quality Time & Connections
- Had a 2-hour phone call with parents, caught up on family news
- Organized a game night with friends (6 people attended)
- Spent Saturday morning hiking with partner, phone-free
- Wrote thank-you notes to 3 people who helped me this month

### Resources
- Book: "The 5 Love Languages" by Gary Chapman - Chapters 1-4
- Article: "How to Have Better Conversations" (Harvard Business Review)
- Podcast: "The School of Greatness" - Episode on relationships

### Reflections
> Realized I've been treating relationships as something to maintain rather than actively nurture. Making intentional time for people I care about (not just fitting them in when convenient) has noticeably improved the quality of those connections.
```

## Week Summary Section

### Purpose
Provide a concise overview of the week's key takeaways, challenges, and forward planning.

### Key Wins üéâ

**What to Include:**
- Most significant achievements of the week
- Meaningful progress on goals
- Breakthroughs or "aha" moments
- Completed milestones

**Guidelines:**
- List 2-4 wins (3 is ideal)
- Be specific: quantify when possible
- Focus on meaningful accomplishments, not just completed tasks
- Celebrate both big and small wins

**Examples:**
```markdown
### Key Wins üéâ
1. Completed and deployed my first full-stack web application to production
2. Reached a 10-week meditation streak - longest consistent habit ever
3. Had a breakthrough conversation with a family member about boundaries
```

### Challenges Faced ü§î

**What to Include:**
- Obstacles encountered during the week
- How you addressed or worked through them
- Lessons learned from difficulties
- Ongoing struggles worth noting

**Guidelines:**
- List 1-3 challenges (2 is typical)
- Include both the challenge AND your response/learning
- Be honest about struggles
- Frame challenges as learning opportunities

**Examples:**
```markdown
### Challenges Faced ü§î
1. Struggled with async JavaScript concepts - spent extra time building projects to practice rather than just reading documentation
2. Felt overwhelmed balancing learning time with work commitments - adjusted schedule to focus on one main topic per day instead of trying to do everything
```

### Looking Ahead üëÄ

**What to Include:**
- Plans for the coming week
- Areas you want to focus on or improve
- Anticipated challenges or opportunities
- Continuations of current learning paths

**Guidelines:**
- List 2-5 forward-looking items
- Be specific but not overly detailed
- Include both continuation and new focus areas
- Balance ambition with realism

**Examples:**
```markdown
### Looking Ahead üëÄ
- Continue building React projects, focusing on custom hooks
- Start "Deep Work" book and implement time-blocking strategy
- Research index fund options for investment account opening
- Plan spring hiking trip with friends
```

## Navigation Links

### Footer Format
Every weekly README must end with navigation links:

```markdown
### Navigation
[‚Üê Previous Week](../week-XX/README.md) | [Main README](../../../README.md) | [Next Week ‚Üí](../week-XX/README.md)
```

### Link Calculation Rules

**Previous Week Link:**
- Format: `../week-XX/README.md`
- For Week 01: Can point to main README or be omitted
- For Week 02+: Points to previous week (Week 02 ‚Üí Week 01)
- Use relative path (../ goes up one directory)

**Main README Link:**
- Format: `../../../README.md`
- Always points to repository root README
- Same for all weeks: up 3 levels (week folder ‚Üí year folder ‚Üí weeks folder ‚Üí root)

**Next Week Link:**
- Format: `../week-XX/README.md`
- For most recent week: Can be incomplete or point to main README
- For older weeks: Points to next week (Week 01 ‚Üí Week 02)
- Update when new weeks are added

### Examples by Position

**Week 01 (First Week):**
```markdown
[Main README](../../../README.md) | [Next Week ‚Üí](../week-02/README.md)
```

**Week 02 (Middle Week):**
```markdown
[‚Üê Previous Week](../week-01/README.md) | [Main README](../../../README.md) | [Next Week ‚Üí](../week-03/README.md)
```

**Week 52 (Latest Week):**
```markdown
[‚Üê Previous Week](../week-51/README.md) | [Main README](../../../README.md)
```

## Content Creation Workflow

### Step 1: Copy Template
```bash
cp weeks/TEMPLATE.md weeks/2026/week-XX/README.md
```

### Step 2: Update Header
Use datetime.skill to determine:
- Week number (XX)
- Year (YYYY)
- Date range (Month DD - Month DD)

```markdown
# Week 01, 2026 (January 17 - January 23)
```

### Step 3: Write Week at a Glance
Craft a 1-2 sentence summary capturing:
- Main focus or theme of the week
- Key achievement or learning
- Context that makes it interesting

**Good Examples:**
> **Week at a Glance**: Dove deep into React hooks this week, building three projects that finally made state management click. Also started tracking finances more carefully after reading about compound interest.

> **Week at a Glance**: First week of structured learning! Set up this journal system and explored multiple domains. Excited to see this grow over time.

**Avoid:**
- Too vague: "Learned some stuff and did things"
- Too long: More than 2-3 sentences
- Just listing: "Did AI, finance, and fitness"

### Step 4: Fill Topic Sections
For each of the six topics:
1. Decide if you have content (it's OK to skip topics some weeks)
2. If yes, fill in relevant subsections
3. Include at least "What I Learned" and "Reflections"
4. Other subsections can be empty if no content

**Handling Empty Topics:**
- Option 1: Remove the entire topic section (not recommended - breaks structure)
- Option 2: Leave section with empty subsections (recommended - maintains structure)
- Option 3: Add a brief note: "No significant learning in this area this week"

### Step 5: Complete Week Summary
- Add 2-4 key wins (meaningful accomplishments)
- Add 1-3 challenges (with how you addressed them)
- Add 2-5 forward-looking items

### Step 6: Update Navigation
- Calculate previous week number (current - 1)
- Update Previous Week link if not Week 01
- Leave Next Week link empty if this is the latest week
- Verify relative paths are correct

### Step 7: Review and Polish
Use content-format.skill standards:
- Check markdown syntax
- Ensure consistent formatting
- Verify headers follow hierarchy
- Test that structure is complete
- Proofread for typos

## Quality Checklist

### Structure ‚úì
- [ ] Title with correct week number, year, and date range
- [ ] "Week at a Glance" summary present
- [ ] All six topic sections included (even if some are empty)
- [ ] Week Summary section with three subsections
- [ ] Navigation footer with correct links

### Content ‚úì
- [ ] At least 2-3 topics have meaningful content
- [ ] Reflections are personal and thoughtful
- [ ] Resources include links where applicable
- [ ] Specific rather than vague throughout
- [ ] Week summary captures key points

### Formatting ‚úì
- [ ] Markdown syntax is correct
- [ ] Headers follow proper hierarchy (H1 ‚Üí H2 ‚Üí H3)
- [ ] Consistent use of emojis in headers
- [ ] Lists are properly formatted
- [ ] Blockquotes used for reflections
- [ ] Horizontal rules separate sections

### Links ‚úì
- [ ] Navigation links use correct relative paths
- [ ] Previous week link points to correct week (or omitted for Week 01)
- [ ] Main README link goes up three levels
- [ ] Next week link present if not latest week
- [ ] Resource links are properly formatted

## Common Mistakes

### Structural Issues
‚ùå Wrong header level for topics (using H3 instead of H2)
‚ùå Missing topic sections entirely
‚ùå Incorrect emoji for topics
‚ùå Missing Week Summary section

### Content Issues
‚ùå Vague statements: "Learned about programming"
‚ùå Empty sections left as just "-"
‚ùå No reflections (most important personal touch)
‚ùå Week summary doesn't match weekly content

### Formatting Issues
‚ùå Inconsistent spacing between sections
‚ùå Wrong blockquote usage (not using > for reflections)
‚ùå Link formatting errors
‚ùå Missing horizontal rule separators

### Navigation Issues
‚ùå Wrong relative path depth (../week-XX vs ../../week-XX)
‚ùå Not updating previous weeks' "Next Week" links
‚ùå Incorrect week numbers in links
‚ùå Broken links due to typos

## Integration with Other Skills

### With datetime.skill.md
- Calculate correct week numbers and date ranges
- Ensure dates in header match week structure

### With content-format.skill.md
- Apply formatting standards to all content
- Ensure visual appeal and readability

### With readme-updater.skill.md
- Provide information for main README updates
- Ensure consistency between weekly and main README

### With topic-navigator.skill.md
- Maintain consistent topic categorization
- Enable proper cross-referencing

---

**Skill Version**: 1.0  
**Last Updated**: 2026-01-17  
**Template Location**: `/weeks/TEMPLATE.md`  
**Example Weeks**: `/weeks/2026/week-01/README.md`, `/weeks/2026/week-02/README.md`

*This skill ensures every weekly entry maintains high quality, consistent structure, and meaningful documentation of learning progress.*
